title: John Smit on the complete role reversal from the South Africa vs England 2007 Rugby World Cup final
text:
Twelve years ago, Eddie Jones was on the other side. England were playing South Africa in the World Cup final and the Aussie coach had been up to his usual tricks.

John Smit, who was Springboks captain at the time, remembers the first training session after Jones was drafted in to help head coach Jake White. 'We were doing a run-through and we thought it had gone pretty well,' Smit tells Sportsmail.

'We got in a huddle and I said, 'Eddie, what do you think?' 'He said, 'Hmm, yeah mate, I reckon it's a four out of 10'.

Eddie Jones came into the South Africa set-up back in 2007 and lifted the standards

John Smit (right) captained South Africa to victory over Johnny Wilkinson and England

‘He raised our standards straight away. He was really good for us. He wasn’t really the head coach, standing up in the front and talking. But he helped, he absorbed a bit of the pressure.’

South Africa had thrashed England in the pool stages, before meeting them again in the final five weeks later. England were overwhelming underdogs and lost 15-6. But Smit believes the balance of power has now firmly been flipped on its head.

‘The only similarity is that it’s the same countries,’ Smit says. ‘Everything else is different. Different playing styles, coaching styles, different journeys.

‘In 2007, England were the underdogs because we’d beaten them 36-0 five weeks earlier.

South Africa were clearly the best side in the world when they beat England in France

'It’s hard to explain how big it would be for South Africa to win. I don’t think anything can have a bigger effect on our country than a game like this. I never realised until I got back from Paris in 2007. All walks of life, all colours, all sizes, all languages, it’s the most uniting tool we have as a country.

‘Around 18 months ago, if you’d offered any South Africa supporter a quarter-final, they would have bitten your arm off. On semi-final form, it’s a game England would expect to win. You’d be a brave man to put your money on South Africa.’

In 2011, Smit moved to Saracens, where he witnessed the emergence of their golden generation including Owen Farrell, who he calls ‘Faz’, Maro Itoje and the Vunipola brothers. As a fellow hooker, Smit worked closely with Jamie George, and he believes the club’s winning mentality will come to the fore this week.

‘The spine of the English team is built around Saracens,’ says Smit. ‘They’re well accustomed to these grand final scenarios.

Smit played alongside Owen Farrell (left) at Saracens and was struck by his dedication

‘Those guys were kids when I joined Saracens but they didn’t come across as kids. They had built quite a bond in the academy and were motivated athletes who wanted to achieve.

‘Eddie’s been pretty fortunate to get these players at a time when Saracens are probably the strongest team in the world.

‘Jamie George was one of the most co-operative students I’ve ever come across. He was hungry to learn, to listen, to work. He is unbelievably well-balanced, carries well, has a huge work-rate, knows when to pop and when to hold. He’s the complete No 2. It was obvious he was going to go all the way, like all those guys.

‘Faz was a special player, the integral cog in that machine with the way he captains and manages the game.’

Smit believes Sarries and England play from similar blueprints. ‘Watching the semi-final reminded me of one of those clinical Heineken Cup performances. They did more than just beat them up. They did them at the collision, but they also took risks and offloaded some balls. I can’t see them deviating from that. If they get that right again, I don’t see England not pulling through.’

Smit expects South Africa to continue with their simplistic style many have called boring

Nor does he think South Africa will deviate much from their ‘boring’ style. ‘It’s absolutely boring,’ Smit says. ‘But people must understand the journey of South Africa. Rassie Erasmus has had 18 months and he’s got these guys to focus on their biggest strengths: their pack, increasing the physicality in defence and aligning that with a kicking game.

‘South Africa have nothing pretty about them. It doesn’t take a genius to work out how they play. The difficulty is trying to stop them. They don’t care what people say about their style. It’s not pretty. The 2007 final was probably the worst game of rugby ever played!’

And Smit — and Jones — know how that turned out.
